) or
(Ђаковица,
) is a city in western
with about 150,000 inhabitants.
Gjakova was badly hit by the Kosovo War of 1998–99, fought between Kosovo Liberation Army guerrillas demanding the independence of then-autonomous province of Kosovo and

, or Federal Republic of Yugoslavia as it was known then. Around 75% of town's population was driven out by Serbian Army during the war, and much of city's buildings were burnt or otherwise destroyed—by both sides of belligerents, as it seems. After the war, much of town's ethnic Albanian inhabitants returned (who now make up to 95% of the population), but it was the local Serbs to be exiled this time. Many of the stores at the downtown area, locally known as

, were rebuilt.

While in Gjakova, make sure you talk to the locals, especially the young ones, since they're more proficient in English. And you will hear a story about every corner of the city. Talking about the past is a very actual subject,  but people avoid it since many families there have lost at least one dear member.

Almost every inhabitant of the town has relatives in Switzerland or Germany. So especially during the summer months you will see many expensive foreign cars from these countries circling around the city. The foreign family members come here for vacation as well for marriages because this way the whole family can join the wedding. The village is specialized on marriages so that you will find an unexpected number of shops specialized to this.
From Albania there are minibuses from
via the Lake Koman/Lake Fierza and

. There is also a Minibus (called "Furgon" in Albanian) directly from Bajram Curry that starts at 8 AM.
The city can also be reached directly by bus from every city in the Kosovo.

Since the city is not that big, the best way to get to see it is by walking. 
Taxis are quite cheap, you can get around the city for €2-3 tops.

Almost all of the old architecture has been rebuilt after the destruction during the war. So enjoy the walk through the nice old town. There you should visit the old guesthouse/restaurant from the 19th century and the small street with shops specialized in woodworks. The church and the main mosque have also been rebuilt and can be visited (opening times change).

The

is worth visiting! It's close to the airport, 7 km away. Taking a cab to there wouldn't cost more than €15. Beware though, it's the drinking water source of the town, therefore swimming is prohibited!
Gjakova city offers many things to do, and the prices too are low.
There are countless shops offering "Bling Bling" products like jewellery, wedding dresses, blinking high heels etc.. There are also special hair dressing stores that attracts women even from Albania.
There are two classy traditional restaurants in Gjakove.

value: ) is on the top of the hill overlooking the city. Take a cab and within 10 minutes you'll be there enjoying a wonderful view of the city. They serve excellent and cheap traditional Albanian food which includes proper 300-gram beef steaks (for €6) and fresh salads with olives, tomatoes, cucumbers, and onions and many other local dishes. Beers for €1.
, in an old traditional house built during the WWI which has a nice cobblestone garden, serves excellent food and reasonable pricing.
There also is a good fish restaurant called

. It serves good fish and it's possibly the cheapest one you can get in Gjakova, along with various fresh salads, and traditional baked fish. In addition, they serve good beef steaks and many other local dishes, the coffee is also good and there is free wireless.

There are plenty of
in Qarshia e Vogel (downtown) where you can go and have a Peja beer, relax and eventually meet youngs which would be excited to meet someone new in town.

is pretty active during summer time. Young crowds go out on a promenade on the main street and then end up in bars and clubs. There live music during weekends, either Rock or Albanian folk music (mainly in restaurants on wedding occasions).

One of the best places to go is

, cheap prices and good music. Also well-known local band called "NA" plays live every Wednesday night. So don't miss it!

Domestically brewed
is a must.
are bit hard to find. Long drinks cost not more than €2-3. Tipping is not mandatory but probably highly appreciated!

are also cheap. In any given bar/pub you can taste the home make Raki for €1 per shot (at least 5 cl that is). There are 2 clubs in town which are usually open on Fridays and Saturdays! The city is quite crowded especially during summer time due to large numbers of expats visiting friends and family!

value: directions=From main square, go down towards the Old Market
content=Authentic cuisine and construction in the old part of town. Walking distance from main spots.

directions=Entering from Pristina, take the transit road, make a right on Scanderbeg street at the end of it, then a left on the first main crossing. From Prizren, continue on Scanderbeg main street, make a left on the first main street.
content=Modern construction with red bricks in the New Block/Orize neighborhood part of town. Easy access by car.
content= Large hotel in the center of the city. Includes swimming pool and fitness center.
directions= On the outskirts entering town from Prishtina
content=Double rooms with jacuzzi and Internet access.

You can walk at any time at night in the city and not be worried about anything! Have fun and enjoy!
Travelling from Gjakova without a rented car or a taxi is only possible in the morning at 6 AM. The bus company "Meti Comerc" runs buses to international directions like
in Montenegro,
or

in Albania. It is advised that you book a day in advance because in summer the buses can be full.
To other cities in the Kosovo there are some minibuses - ask in the travel agencies.
All buses start in front of the nowadays closed main bus station north of the Hotel Pashtriku.
